poem:
The Tomb

In desert's ancient whisper—  
sand shifts, secrets  
unfurl with sunlit silence,  
a hollowed stone cradles  
Thutmose's dust, times  
past and dreamed collide.  
Echoes of chisels,  
awed breaths haunt  
this hollow choir,  
as Piers unearths,  
beneath time's sleeping layer—  
history cradled,  
resurrected by curious hands.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘You dream about such things’: Brit who discovered missing pharaoh’s tomb may have unearthed another To uncover the location of one long-lost pharaoh’s tomb is a career-defining moment for an archaeologist. But to find a second is the stuff of dreams. Last week British archaeologist Piers Litherland announced the find of the century – the first discovery of a rock-cut pharaoh’s tomb in Egypt since Tutankhamun’s in 1922. His team found the pharaoh Thutmose II’s". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
